Tromping back and forth to the bathroom was a pain.  For guys there is one bathroom upstairs and a one-stall bathroom on the main level near the area where drinks are sold. There were very long lines for the men's bathroom as well as the women's.  
There really aren't any hotels within walking distance that we saw.

Overall, this is a beautiful venue and would be great for certain events, but for concerts where you want to move around, it isn't ideal.

Your theater provides great sound, comfortable seats and a awesome environment!!  We are not familiar with Des Moines so parking was hard for us to figure out!!  Would of been nice if we would of been advised prior and then told that lots of the hospital parking was off limits!!
If you have the chance to see a show/event here do it.!!!!  Phenomenal!!! Well worth our trip fr Cedar Rapids

We came to DesMoines from Milwaukee for a concert not knowing anything about this venue.  Based on pics, we knew it was an older/vintage place.  I sure wish we would have arrived earlier to take in all it's beauty.  There's so much more than a concert/theater.  Not only is the place stunning, but the people who worked there are very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful.  Arrive early would be my suggestion to anyone coming here for an event.
Theater just happened to be in the neighborhood we were visiting from out of state. Gary Allan was performing so we timed our visit perfectly. Quaint theater that rocked the night.

Classy old theater, beautifully preserved. Box seating is very comfortable, and provides a great view of stage. Great acoustics. Lovely bits of history scattered throughout the lobby areas. Elevator access to the main and balcony floors, with adequate disabled parking spaces and access. Bathroom facilities were clean, though not that conveniently located for the ladies.

name: Robert D. Ray Asian Gardens
reviews: the Asian gardens is a great place to go to on a sunny day!It's a  great place to take pictures and share with your friends.👍
It is such a beautiful place. I always bring my family here when they visit from out of the state! Lovely

I checked out the garden during my morning run. It's really small and it doesn't take more than 15 minutes to check it out. I don't think it's worth a detour, but it was along my route and it sort of cheered my up as it was such a contrast to the surrounding area.

Everywhere we looked, the Asian Gardens were in need of help.  The gardens were overgrown with weeds and brush.  The ponds some were dried out and others were filled.  Either way they all needed cleaning as does the garden's iconic Asian building.  The accent hardscapes were either broken and/or non-functioning.
This is just down from the botanical gardens and along the river walk. not a lot to do or see but the building is neat and the statues are interesting, but nothing great.

name: Confluence Brewing Company
reviews: Don't let the outside appearance fool you. It's what's inside that counts. The wide choice of great tasting beers is great! Big tasting room and also large outdoor seating area. You can sample flights to determine which beers you like. Fun place. Parking can be difficult if they're hosting a large party, which happened when we visited.

We were a party of four and all had a great time.

Each of us started with a flight of beer.  There were eleven choices that were all very good.  Each flight cost $8.

Because Confluence does not sell food we brought our own pretzels and then ordered pizza that was dleivered to the Tap Room.

Cash only but there is an ATM inside the building.

With the deck overlooking Grays Lake, this is a definite return trip when the weather warms up.
The staff was great and very attentive. You can bring in food and game from the outside which added to the experience. We will be back!

Went with my sons (16 & 11).  They had root beer. Locally made. Loved it.  I tried a flight of 4 beers.  It’s off the beaten path from Des Moines, but totally worth a visit. Clean facility & happy staff.

This is a good example of revitalizing old warehouses into more 21st Century gathering space. The large space seems to be well utilized to brew beers. I read the chalkboard stating that they had a new beer every Friday and the names of the beers were unique and had names of Des Moines landmarks. There was a bicycle path nearby. The cyclists would pop-in to ‘re-fuel’ or recharge before moving on! Quite a mixed crowd – parents with young children; adults and of course always-present millennials at any good beer-tap!
Our group tried a few beers. All beers we tasted were of good quality.

First of all, Confluence is great inside. Very modern and cool and just a nice place to sit with friends and have some drinks. 

Being our first time here, we ordered a couple flights for our group and we shared them. My wife is gluten free and was able to find some great GF options. 

Nearly all of the beers served here are great. High quality, craft beers served by friendly and engaging staff. What more could you ask for?

-The Power Trippers
This is located in an odd place I think, but who cares when the atmosphere and beer is delicious! Worth a visit...or two...or three...

Don't let the outside appearance fool you. It's what's inside that counts. The wide choice of great tasting beers is great! Big tasting room and also large outdoor seating area. You can sample flights to determine which beers you like. Fun place. Parking can be difficult if they're hosting a large party, which happened when we visited.

name: Clive Greenbelt Trail
reviews: I regularly run the Clive Greenbelt. It is well-maintained, and beautiful! I frequently see deer. I feel safe on the Clive Greenbelt Trail because it is well-traveled and I often see Clive policemen on bicycles patrolling the trail. Several parks along the trail provide drinking fountains, trash receptacles, and bathroom facilities. There are also benches along the way if you want to sit and watch the beautiful creek and enjoy nature. There's even a nice Little Free Library near the Clive Aquatic Center!

I have ridden my bike on this trail several times.  It is a flat ride along a stream with a pretty view of trees and birds and landscaping.  Each time I was on a longer ride and used part of this trail in my journey.  If you love to walk or jog or run or bike, then this trail is a great place to exercise and enjoy nature.

You can often see deer along the trail.  Especially near sunset.  Sometimes, turkey.  

When in town, I like to go here.  Path is generally well maintained and runs alongside a creek.  It runs under street bridges and there are some pedestrian bridges across the creek.  

Many people use this trail to commute via bicycle all over town.  It links up with other trails and so it's possible to think in terms of over 200 Kms of trails from this one trail.
You can get to just about anywhere in the DSM area via the trail.  It's paved, in pretty good condition.
Whether you're biking or hiking, the greenbelt in Clive is simply wonderful. You're likely to come across deer, which makes it that much more interesting.
Nice trail for walking or bikers. Small play area for kids near the restrooms. Water, wildflowers and wildlife can be seen and enjoyed.

nice refreshing trail to walk in. the only issues is with the bugs and the overgrown bushes. 
not many bicycle riders on the trail.

This trail has it all. Wide paved bike and walking path. Scenery though treed areas and sunny paths. Seating when needed, and stops with restrooms. Several areas were recently modified to make them safer for the faster moving bikers and runners.

name: Court Avenue
reviews:
Spring, summer and autumn offers the Saturday morning Farmer's Market (ranked #2 in the nation after Pike's Place in Seattle).  

There are bars, restaurants, cafes, and the Science Center with the Imax theater.

Boundary on one end by the courthouse and the other end by the river (which has a nice walking trail and city scenery), the Court Avenue district is fun.  

Night when the bars close can get unsafe.  Over drinking and macho attitudes.  The rest of the time, it's not only safe for kids and families, but actually a must visit.  

Java Joe's is on a side street.  Spaghetti Works on the main, and one of the entrances to the Skywalk is in Court Avenue Brewery building.

It's actually a lot of fun once you get down there on a Friday or Saturday night. It's pretty safe (there's always police about to ensure that) it's a decent atmosphere as long as the weather is nice!

There is always something happening on Court Ave. From the farmers market on Saturday mornings. With lots of vendors to choose from to music and even flash mobs to watch. Then at night there are restaurants and bars for the night life. Thought out the srping and summer there are lots of different events happening all the time. Here is a link to see up coming events in Des Moines and the Court Avenue area. http://www.catchdesmoines.com/events/

Once the sun goes down, this place is a pretty cool.  But there are almost always some challenges with drunks or fights...at least every time I have been there.  There have also been a few epic conflicts with lots of folks involved.  Get a sitter for the kids.

This is the place to hang out downtown. They've got many good places to eat, the farmer's market is on Saturday mornings, and parking is close and plentiful. We came here last for the Des Moines marathon and had a wonderful time.

Coming from Europe the structure of DSM down town feel strange; mainly office buildings without shops on the street level. That's why the streets are quite empty. People move from one to another building along the skywalks. Court Avenue differs from the rest of down town. There's lots of pubs and restaurants restaurants side by side which makes it perfect for pub crawls. However, the area doesn't differ from similar areas we've seen in every city we've visited and as we're not in a party mood, we just went through a couple of times until we decided to cross the river to East Village where we found more peaceful places.
Lot of choices for food and drink in downtown DSM.  The night life gets going around 10pm so if your not into that, come early and enjoy..
Whether you're looking for a watering hole or meal, Court Avenue district is a must-go. Great variety of restaurants and bars. Many of the buildings are architecturally significant.

name: Terrace Hill
reviews:
Whenever we visit a capital city, we always visit the state capitol building.  If our days in the city coincide with tour days at the state governor's mansion, we make plans to also tour the mansion.  We love the history, architecture, and art that is part of these tours as well as the opportunity to interact with locals who love their state and history.
  
Check the Terrace Hill website to learn of tour days and times.  At the time of our travel, the fee for the mansion tour was $5 -- certainly reasonable and fine with us to pay a small fee to help maintain the beautiful, historic structure.
 
Prior to the tour, we took a look around the carriage house building which now houses staff, displays, and a small gift shop.  An excellent video was shown as an introduction to the tour.  Our excellent guide, Patty, walked with us to the mansion and imparted more details and stories about the mansion as we toured inside and out.
  
The day was a little rainy, and umbrellas were provided for the short walk from the carriage house to the mansion.  Street parking and handicapped parking is available on Forest Drive, which is on the west side of the property.  Additional parking is located in the Terrace Hill parking lot off of Grand Avenue at Forest Drive.
Some of the history of Des Moines preserved in this building.  Nice to see it is well cared for, and worth the trip.

We made the 10:30 tour with Rhonda who introduced the 15 minute video presented in the old carriage house giving the history of the place from construction to now being the Governors Mansion.
Then it was across the lawns to the main house and what a spectacular property it is.
It is a must see if you enjoy living history and even if you don't!

We arrived on a cold Saturday in time for the 11:30 tour.  I was surprised at how many others joined us.  Our tour guide, John is clearly in love with this building, flaws and all.  He points out mistakes, tells stories and jokes and gives you a great historical perspective.  Well worth $5.  Beautiful 150 year old building.  Don't miss the early Grant Woods painting in the upstairs hallway.

We watched a 15 minute video and then were escorted on a tour. The lady volunteer was informative and enjoyable. She provided a lot of family information, building details, and interesting events and visitors to the mansion. Parking is near the entrance road just off Grand Ave, so there is a climb up the hill to the offices. I recommend one take the time to see this nice old building. It is period furnished and photography is allowed.

It’s probably just me, but I am uncomfortable touring a house that people live in.  Since this is the governor’s house, the family was there on my tour out in the backyard.  You only get to see the first and second floor, and family lives on the third floor, but the kids were out playing in the backyard I felt like I was intruding.  The tour starts in the carriage house, and they have the history of the house and a short film which is very good witch actors portraying the families that lived in the house.  Then you walk over to the house.  You can take pictures of the outside, but none on the inside which is a shame since it is spectacular.  My tour guide was very good, and I ended up taking the tour solo so we could talk.  If you like Victorian style old houses, this one is a treat.  From crystal chandeliers to hand carved woodwork, it really is spectacular.  Parking is on the street, which is narrow and winding.

This is a lovely home with a fascinating history. However, the tour is longer than necessary for the size of the building. Most, if not all, of the interesting information can be learned via the plaques and the video they show. I found myself getting bored waiting for the tour to move from one room to another. I’m also saddened a bit that the carriage house was modernized instead of preserved as it was originally, though I understand why that was done; I feel the sane way about the swimming pool. The highlight of the home is the magnificent stained glass. I would recommend checking it out, especially if you love old buildings, but for me it was a one-and-done experience. I don’t intend to go back for a second tour.
Too beautiful for words.  Beautiful gardens, excellent tour guides, so much history and a Windsor in the mix no one can explain.  Such a mystery!  Where did she hide during the war?

This 150-year-old home (built in 1869) is now the governor's official residence. But they do tours and it's well worth your time. It truly is a set back in history. One suggestion: Do a bit of research on it before you go; it makes it much more meaningful that way.

Whenever we visit a capital city, we always visit the state capitol building.  If our days in the city coincide with tour days at the state governor's mansion, we make plans to also tour the mansion.  We love the history, architecture, and art that is part of these tours as well as the opportunity to interact with locals who love their state and history.
  
Check the Terrace Hill website to learn of tour days and times.  At the time of our travel, the fee for the mansion tour was $5 -- certainly reasonable and fine with us to pay a small fee to help maintain the beautiful, historic structure.
 
Prior to the tour, we took a look around the carriage house building which now houses staff, displays, and a small gift shop.  An excellent video was shown as an introduction to the tour.  Our excellent guide, Patty, walked with us to the mansion and imparted more details and stories about the mansion as we toured inside and out.
  
The day was a little rainy, and umbrellas were provided for the short walk from the carriage house to the mansion.  Street parking and handicapped parking is available on Forest Drive, which is on the west side of the property.  Additional parking is located in the Terrace Hill parking lot off of Grand Avenue at Forest Drive.

It was like a living museum. As the residence of the governor, people actually live here and events are held in the rooms, so it's not a dusty museum. However, there is quite a bit of history to learn. Small group tours are great.

name: Brass Armadillo Antique Mall
reviews: Although it’s a little difficult to get to, it’s quick right off the interstate.  Plenty of cases and hundreds of booths to look through. Found a great selection of historic pieces and many hidden treasures. Spent some time in this as we traveled through. Worth stopping into while searching for treasure.
Open late, huge - seriously, huge- selection. Clean building/ restrooms & friendly staff. Coffee & vending machines. Great experience had!

I became acquainted with Brass Armadillo in Wheatridge, Colorado several years ago and it is a MUST stop each time I'm near Denver.  I stopped at the Des Moines location two years ago (amazed to see a mall of the same name) and found that this is the original mall of six.

In the past two years the inventory has completely changed, and this time there was a significant amount of great oak and maple furniture, at good prices.  The mall is huge, so bring good walking shoes and plan to spend an afternoon (several hours) to walk the entire place and take more than a passing glance at the items.

They have a mall "guide" at the front, along with pencils, so that as you walk through you can register booth numbers and locations (aisles are named for various states and cities -- Des Moines Ave., Missouri Ave, Tuscon Ave., etc.) to help you find that special treasure again.

The staff members is all 3 locations I've visited are always pleasant and helpful.  

If you love antiques, this is a MUST stop (actually all of their locations, as each is a bit different).
Walk slow and look in every corner... a lot to see in a lot of places...kind of pricey on some things but ask for discounts...I'm going back in morning to see the next half...enjoy your trip....
Whenever we are in the area we stop even if it delays our trip an hour or four. Always new things to see & reasonable prices. Usually a sale which is always nice. Open 7 days a week.

As to be expected for an overpriced antique store! The place is clean, the staff are friendly so the overly priced items isn’t their fault! But I literally couldn’t find anything that wasn’t seriously overpriced just because it was in the “antique” store! Have fun trying to find something! I did find a brand new Trump 2020 hat for only $10! So that’s awesome!

Sunday about 11 am place was busy parking lot full . This place is inviting clean organized and help is everywhere. Only a few empty locations and price's were about average. Found items I have already and just didn't get anything today. I will come back mid week when I'm not excusing myself so much.

Huge place with a wide variety of items. We saw it from the highway and after getting turned around a couple of times, we found it and were pleasantly surprised. Lots of different things for every collector.

name: Easter Lake Park
reviews: The lake is still being dredged, but it is worth stopping to see the only covered bridge in Polk County, Iowa.

Easter Lake park in Des Moines is located in the SE corner of the city, touching the countryside. A huge project is (for the most part) now completed, leaving the lake full of water and the park serene and welcoming. New bike trails have been added along with a bridge, connecting the two sides. This park is an ideal day trip for a picnic, kayaking, running, biking, or a Sunday drive.

After a lengthy lake and watershed restoration project, the lake is again full.  Fishing will not be good until next year as they get the lake re-stocked.  The 12' walking trail completely circles the lake now with the installation of a pedestrian bridge at the west end of the lake.  New sand is in place at the swimming beach and there are multiple shelters on the south side of the lake available for gatherings.  Amazing how close it is to the city center, yet still with a very rural feel when you get on the trail.

A peaceful little lake with a lot of activities available for all walks of life. The walking/running path was excellent especially when highlighted with the fantastic bridge. The shelters were a wonderful low-cost venue for a wedding with nearby restrooms and parking.

This park has really upped its game.  Recently they completed a nice bike/walking trail all of the way around the lake (about 5 miles).  The path is smooth wide concrete and has several scenic bridges.  They also drained and dreged the lake so the water is deeper and cleaner and built multiple fishing jetties and docks.  In a couple of years this should be a top notch fishing destination.  Other items my family enjoys are picnic areas, multiple playgrounds, and the beach which is nice as far as Iowa lake beaches go and has concessions, boat rentals, showers, and changing rooms.

After a lengthy lake and watershed restoration project, the lake is again full.  Fishing will not be good until next year as they get the lake re-stocked.  The 12' walking trail completely circles the lake now with the installation of a pedestrian bridge at the west end of the lake.  New sand is in place at the swimming beach and there are multiple shelters on the south side of the lake available for gatherings.  Amazing how close it is to the city center, yet still with a very rural feel when you get on the trail.

Easter Lake park in Des Moines is located in the SE corner of the city, touching the countryside. A huge project is (for the most part) now completed, leaving the lake full of water and the park serene and welcoming. New bike trails have been added along with a bridge, connecting the two sides. This park is an ideal day trip for a picnic, kayaking, running, biking, or a Sunday drive.
The lake is still being dredged, but it is worth stopping to see the only covered bridge in Polk County, Iowa.

name: Better Homes and Gardens Test Garden
reviews: It was pleasant to walk through and see a variety of plants and shrubs that don't necessarily grow in my zone. The two women who maintain the gardens were interesting to chat with and it was an opportunity to learn about the gardens and how they use them in the magazine.

The BH&G Gardens are truly beautiful. You can catch a glimpse from the sidewalks or plan a visit around the open dates they offer.
BH&G use the gardens as test plots and to provide a place of escape for their employees. While not Butchart Gardens they are worth a trip to enjoy the country in the middle of the city.

BH&G took us on a private tour. Well worth the time to see all the
seasonal plants and flowers in bloom. The guide was knowledgeable and does a fantastic job

I love to garden, and this is a wonderful place to stop and spend some time.  Combine this trip with a stop at a unique and local restaurant for a special outing.  
Make sure to check the open hours and days-closed to the public most of the time.  Well worth the trip, though.

I love to garden, and this is a wonderful place to stop and spend some time.  Combine this trip with a stop at a unique and local restaurant for a special outing.  
Make sure to check the open hours and days-closed to the public most of the time.  Well worth the trip, though.
You can walk here on Friday afternoon's and enjoy the well maintained garden or even take pictures.  People of all ages come here.  I recommend especially when the Art Festival is open nearby.

It may have just been the weather, but the gardens looked very parched. I arrived with a stroller, only to find out you have to walk down approximately 6 steps to get into the garden. It is not handicap accessible! Perhaps if I had a guided tour I would have enjoyed it more. It was underwhelming.

It was pleasant to walk through and see a variety of plants and shrubs that don't necessarily grow in my zone. The two women who maintain the gardens were interesting to chat with and it was an opportunity to learn about the gardens and how they use them in the magazine.

The BH&G Gardens are truly beautiful. You can catch a glimpse from the sidewalks or plan a visit around the open dates they offer.
BH&G use the gardens as test plots and to provide a place of escape for their employees. While not Butchart Gardens they are worth a trip to enjoy the country in the middle of the city.
You need to stop at this place ... Very knowledgeable information shared by guides, Andrea and Sandra. Thank you ladies, it was a great visit even though it was raining.

My husband & I enjoyed a stroll through the gardens. Master gardeners were available to answer questions. Learned a few things while enjoying the beautiful gardens. Make sure to check the schedule for hours of operation.

name: Des Moines River Trail
reviews:
The Des Moines River Trail is part of the Iowa trail network, and somewhat follows the south side of the river. Near downtown, you stay within sight of the river and travel along one of the main routes east-west in Des Moines. It includes an emergency bike repair stand just across bridge from the stadium.

Check it out if you're looking for a less crowded trip than Gray's Lake.

I'm reviewing this as a cyclist, not a pedestrian, who may have different preferences.

This is a nice trail in the heart of the city.  It follows the river which is channelized here but still interesting.  There are a bunch of interesting old buildings along the river and the trail runs along both sides allowing for several loop options.  There is a lot of construction work right now so some sections are not accessible and some of the gardens are closed but it still makes for a nice walk.  There is bike repair station with a tire pump and tools if you are biking and need a quick repair.  This is a nice touch.

A city isn't a real one unless it has a harbour or a river is running through. The Des Moines River is dividing the city between down town and East Village. I've done my morning runs along the river up and down on both sides. Well, I've seen more pleasant river sides, but it's absolutely worth the walk. In some places there's some construction work going in so i just had to switch to the other side. In the upper end there's the Rotary Riverside Park for kids that is just being extended with a skateboarding park and on the opposite side there's the tiny Asian park with the small pagoda. I liked the pedestrian bridge. However I think the city should further development the Riverside.

This area has a few different points of interest.

You have a nice view of the capitol from here.

You can see the Women of Achievement Bridge, and the cute park that looks like a fishing pole with a red and white bobber.

While there, a homeless or transient man was walking, sitting, and lying in the area.  Just be cautious and aware of your surroundings, as you would anywhere.

A city isn't a real one unless it has a harbour or a river is running through. The Des Moines River is dividing the city between down town and East Village. I've done my morning runs along the river up and down on both sides. Well, I've seen more pleasant river sides, but it's absolutely worth the walk. In some places there's some construction work going in so i just had to switch to the other side. In the upper end there's the Rotary Riverside Park for kids that is just being extended with a skateboarding park and on the opposite side there's the tiny Asian park with the small pagoda. I liked the pedestrian bridge. However I think the city should further development the Riverside.
The river is fast flowing, with various nice sigtseeing points, but overall it is not very special, certainly compared to many others in the US or world

I took an hour walk along the river trail. The views were pretty amazing. I was surprise to see how much water was flowing in the river. It was totally full. The path goes up and down and there were many people out enjoying the sunny day.

Just a beautiful walkway by the river and a stunning walking bridge, with two separate arched walkways, and a screaming high flowing waterfall beneath. Excellent spot to walk by the river and have a peaceful time while in the city. 

High water flooded some of the path on the west side. But east was open and good, north of the walking bridge. Great, sunny spring day. Beautiful day for a walk on the river. Great place!! Good job Des Moines!

name: Rotary Riverwalk Park
reviews: Maps takes you to the Dog park on the wrong side of the bridge, so if you want to see the cool stuff drive over by the Botanical gardens and park and walk. The Bridge is neat and little Asian bridge is cool too. But my favorite part was the river itself. Hope we can come back when it’s warmer to walk along the bank!

Past through the park during my morning run. The park was empty then so couldn't really see if it's a place that kids love. The swings looked a bit futuristic to me. They are now extending the area by building a skateboard park next to it. Anyway it's a nice a area and once you're there you should cross the river over the nice "womens bridge" to see the Asian garden on the opposite side.

I was able to walk some of this section of the city on one of rare sunny days I had in early May while visiting. The trail system has an easy map to follow with some interesting stops. I especially liked the Chinese pagoda area and learning about some of the immigrant history of the city. This lovely nearby bridge offered a vehicle-free view of the city.

Awesome bridge over the dam. Fascinating to watch the water fall and swirl. Powerful river in the spring. 
Very cute fishing pole and bobber play area for kids. 

Beautiful, clean bridge and park.
Connects up to the bike and walk path. Can go anywhere on the path up or down river. 

Suggest doing the walking loop across this bridge, then down to the red bridge on south side of Downtown, then walk back up. We did this and enjoyed it!

If you want to bike, walk run, or stroll this is the place to go. You get to exercise, or take photos, all year around and the views are stunning. The trail is always open - even when we have deep snow, you can still walk along the river and take in the changes in seasons.

name: Des Moines Social Club
reviews: I go here for ariel and it's one of the most beautiful places to go to. The classes are excellent and it's just a really cool place. I also enjoy all the art that surrounds it.
We had a group here and between the service and the food it was a lovely experience!  If you have a chance eat here, GO!

I have eaten here before in business and they always do a 1st class job for our company. The presentation is perfect.  Top cut Iowa beef is a must try. The views of Des Moines are outstanding. I learned how to canoe on the river so good memories.

Attended a night of music at the Kum & Go Theatre in the Social Club.  

Just a great experience.  Very quaint and a non-stressful evening.  Unlike larger venues, it wasn't very crowded and was a very pleasant experience.

Parking is really easy, and we parked in the ramp just to the East, pretty convenient.

Definitely will attend events here in the future.
Had a great event here with the Allrecipes Allstars. Fun atmosphere and really cool building. We loved dining on the roof top.

name: Saylorville Trail
reviews: The Saylorville trails are a perfect place for a bike ride. Beautiful scenery throughout and the trails themselves aren't what I would call challenging. A great family outing.
Great area for a walk, run or bike ride ANY Time of year.  Many shaded areas to get out of the sun.  Love an autumn run through!

we started driving across a bridge that run over the lake it is a mile long then we drove over the dam that makes the lake followed the road in to a camp ground and it took us right down to where the water flows out of the dam and forms the Des Moines river again pretty cool area and really good fishing area people were catching fish pretty regular I will fish next time for sure and camp there are trails and swimming near by and a lot of different areas to set up a picnic and just relax when I come back I will need a few days to explore what a great area close to everything but in the woods

I live in Saylorville.  I have ridden my bike on this route many times.  I am usually riding into Des Moines for the Saturday morning Farmers Market.  Other times I ride my bike up to Saylorville Lake or the High Trestle Bridge.  It is a flat, easy bike ride that runs along woods which are along the Des Moines river.  The trail is not usually crowded with other people.  You can ride along in silence and listen to the birds in the trees and look at flowers along the trail and at some open spaces you can see the water flowing in the river.
Walk along the lake, through the woods, stop at the butterfly garden or visitor's center. Get as much exercise as you want in a lovely, lovely setting.
